commentBody:
"Meetings...hashed out sounds wrong to me. The participants hashed out the problem. If you stayed with the original structure of the sentence, a better possible rewrite would be, "On Tuesday, after a series of private meetings...an announcement came that the league had hashed out a deal that had eluded them for decades.

"Dogs are a big deal....So is single malt..." If this were in a magazine piece with an eye to something more literary, rather than a newspaper piece, the singular wold be just fine. The writer is indicating that owning a dog is unusual in other parts of the Punjab, but not why--then he or she lists individually for emphasis other more distinctively British practices enjoyed there. It is an effective literary device that helps underline each item.

replies.commentBody: Actually "series" is the subject of the clause; "of private meetings, etc." is a prepositional phrase modifying "series."  I agree that it would be more logical to say that the participants, not the meetings, did the hashing out.

Thomas, checkout Merriam-Webster's Dictionary of English Usage under "agreement, subject-verb: a bunch of boys."  "A bunch of" like "a series of" acts as modifier or predeterminer; what follows it governs the verb and the sense of the clause.  Most experts now side with this position.
